path_1.title: Men in Black (a.k.a. MIB) (1997)
path_1.feeling: Fun concept, but the slick, quippy spectacle leaves me cold.

path_1.title: Herbie Goes Bananas (1980)
path_1.feeling: Cute in spots, mostly thin kiddie fluff I don’t need.

path_1.title: Waking Life (2001)
path_1.feeling: Loved drifting through ideas and dream logic without plot shackles.

path_1.title: Addams Family Values (1993)
path_1.feeling: Delightfully dark and campy with a sharp wit that mostly lands.

path_1.title: Office Space (1999)
path_1.feeling: Deadpan workplace malaise hits home, even if it leans bro-y.

path_1.title: Match Point (2005)
path_1.feeling: Glossy and chilly

path_1.title: Shoah (1985)
path_1.feeling: Monumental, harrowing testimony that demands attention and respect.

path_1.title: Greed (1924)
path_1.feeling: Bleak human nature rendered with bite

path_1.title: Brazil (1985)
path_1.feeling: Barbed, imaginative satire I enjoyed more for mood than mechanics.

path_1.title: Fly, The (1958)
path_1.feeling: Clever premise and eerie tone, but it keeps me at arm’s length.

path_1.title: Sound of Music, The (1965)
path_1.feeling: Polished and tuneful, yet a bit too saccharine for my taste.

path_1.title: District 9 (2009)
path_1.feeling: Grimy allegory and macho beats drown the empathy for me.

path_1.title: Happy Accidents (2000)
path_1.feeling: Sweet, oddball romance where the sci‑fi is a tender metaphor.

path_1.title: Limitless (2011)
path_1.feeling: Slick what‑if thriller that’s fun even if a little hollow.

path_1.title: Safe (1995)
path_1.feeling: Quietly devastating, feminist and eerie in all the right ways.

path_1.title: Cross of Iron (1977)
path_1.feeling: Gritty and competent war film I respect more than love.

path_1.title: The Proud Rebel (1958)
path_1.feeling: Solid, humane western melodrama with a gentle core.

path_1.title: Squid and the Whale, The (2005)
path_1.feeling: Acerbic and honest

path_1.title: Life and Times of Allen Ginsberg, The (1994)
path_1.feeling: Engaging portrait of a restless mind and era.

path_1.title: The Shape of Water (2017)
path_1.feeling: Lush fairy tale with heart

path_1.title: Trouble with Harry, The (1955)
path_1.feeling: Wry and morbidly playful, pleasant rather than piercing.

path_1.title: Wedding Singer, The (1998)
path_1.feeling: Sweet-natured and nostalgic, if formulaic.

path_1.title: One Day in September (1999)
path_1.feeling: Gripping, sober recounting that balances context and outrage.

path_1.title: Roger & Me (1989)
path_1.feeling: Pointed and funny, though the personalization can feel pushy.

path_1.title: Kid, The (1921)
path_1.feeling: Tender and nimble

path_1.title: Vivre sa vie: Film en douze tableaux (My Life to Live) (1962)
path_1.feeling: Intimate, searching, and formally playful—right up my alley.

path_1.title: Crimes and Misdemeanors (1989)
path_1.feeling: Smartly constructed but emotionally chilly for me.

path_1.title: Election (1999)
path_1.feeling: Razor-sharp, funny, and cruel in ways that illuminate.

path_2.title: Men in Black (a.k.a. MIB) (1997)
path_2.feeling: Slick and quippy but too disposable for me.

path_2.title: Herbie Goes Bananas (1980)
path_2.feeling: Cutesy slapstick left me cold.

path_2.title: Waking Life (2001)
path_2.feeling: Talky, dreamy philosophizing that I happily drifted with.

path_2.title: Addams Family Values (1993)
path_2.feeling: Campy, sharp, and fun, though a bit weightless.

path_2.title: Office Space (1999)
path_2.feeling: Corporate malaise satire hits close, even if bro-y edges date it.

path_2.title: Match Point (2005)
path_2.feeling: I admired the craft, but its chilly moral universe kept me at arm’s length.

path_2.title: Shoah (1985)
path_2.feeling: Monumental, harrowing testimony that demands attention and patience.

path_2.title: Greed (1924)
path_2.feeling: Bleak, biting and impressively modern in its cruelty.

path_2.title: Brazil (1985)
path_2.feeling: Dazzling dystopian satire whose bureaucratic nightmare delights and depresses.

path_2.title: Fly, The (1958)
path_2.feeling: Elegant sci-fi tragedy more affecting than scary for me.

path_2.title: Sound of Music, The (1965)
path_2.feeling: Polished and tuneful, but the sugar overwhelms me.

path_2.title: District 9 (2009)
path_2.feeling: Inventive premise buried under grungy bombast I couldn’t stand.

path_2.title: Happy Accidents (2000)
path_2.feeling: Sweet, oddball time‑twist romance right up my alley.

path_2.title: Limitless (2011)
path_2.feeling: Propulsive, slick thought experiment I enjoy without loving.

path_2.title: Safe (1995)
path_2.feeling: Uneasy, meticulous portrait of illness and isolation that haunts.

path_2.title: Cross of Iron (1977)
path_2.feeling: Gritty and well-staged, though emotionally at a remove for me.

path_2.title: The Proud Rebel (1958)
path_2.feeling: Gentle, humane Western that I respect more than love.

path_2.title: Squid and the Whale, The (2005)
path_2.feeling: Smart and stinging, with just enough warmth to offset the bile.

path_2.title: Life and Times of Allen Ginsberg, The (1994)
path_2.feeling: Engaging portrait that honors the art and the politics.

path_2.title: The Shape of Water (2017)
path_2.feeling: Lush and tender, if a touch too tidy in its myth.

path_2.title: Trouble with Harry, The (1955)
path_2.feeling: Pleasantly morbid trifle, charming more than essential.

path_2.title: Wedding Singer, The (1998)
path_2.feeling: Cute nostalgia, but the humor rarely rises above mild.

path_2.title: One Day in September (1999)
path_2.feeling: Riveting, sobering account delivered with clear-eyed urgency.

path_2.title: Roger & Me (1989)
path_2.feeling: Pointed and funny, even if the tactics are sometimes blunt.

path_2.title: Kid, The (1921)
path_2.feeling: Simple, tender Chaplin blend that still works on me.

path_2.title: Vivre sa vie: Film en douze tableaux (My Life to Live) (1962)
path_2.feeling: Intimate, formally playful study of a woman that moved me.

path_2.title: Crimes and Misdemeanors (1989)
path_2.feeling: Wry and bleak, impressive but emotionally distant for me.

path_2.title: Election (1999)
path_2.feeling: Savage, hilarious civics lesson with teeth.

path_2.title: Men in Black (a.k.a. MIB) (1997)
path_2.feeling: Charming deadpan and clever gizmos, but the slick alien shenanigans keep me at arm’s length

path_2.title: Herbie Goes Bananas (1980)
path_2.feeling: Featherweight kids’ caper with a few cute beats, mostly hollow hijinks

path_2.title: Waking Life (2001)
path_2.feeling: Philosophical drift I often found invigorating, though the noodly navel-gazing wears thin

path_2.title: Addams Family Values (1993)
path_2.feeling: Gleefully macabre and witty, a campy satirical joy with a warm little pulse

path_2.title: Office Space (1999)
path_2.feeling: Dry, relatable cubicle anomie with just enough sardonic bite to stick

path_2.title: Match Point (2005)
path_2.feeling: Glossy fatalism and class envy kept me watching, but its chilly amorality left me unmoved

path_2.title: Shoah (1985)
path_2.feeling: Unflinching, patient testimony that humbled me—formally austere and morally overwhelming

path_2.title: Greed (1924)
path_2.feeling: A stark tragedy of avarice whose moral rot lingers more than its melodrama

path_2.title: Brazil (1985)
path_2.feeling: Baroque dystopian satire that dazzles in bursts but suffocates under its busy whimsy

path_2.title: Fly, The (1958)
path_2.feeling: Tragic sci‑fi fable with a mournful core, more tender than terrifying for me

path_2.title: Sound of Music, The (1965)
path_2.feeling: Irresistible craft and sentiment, even if the sugar rush sometimes blunts the ache

path_2.title: District 9 (2009)
path_2.feeling: Gritty allegory curdles into shrill spectacle—I admired the idea, not the execution

path_2.title: Happy Accidents (2000)
path_2.feeling: A gentle, offbeat time‑love tangle that balances whimsy with sincere, lived‑in feeling

path_2.title: Limitless (2011)
path_2.feeling: Slick high‑concept fun with a propulsive snap—entertaining if a bit hollow

path_2.title: Safe (1995)
path_2.feeling: A quietly terrifying study of illness and identity that seeped under my skin

path_2.title: Cross of Iron (1977)
path_2.feeling: Grimy, fatalistic war menagerie—gripping in patches, but its machismo wears me down

path_2.title: The Proud Rebel (1958)
path_2.feeling: Tender frontier melodrama with a sturdy heart, if familiar beats

path_2.title: Squid and the Whale, The (2005)
path_2.feeling: Acerbic and tender in equal measure

path_2.title: Life and Times of Allen Ginsberg, The (1994)
path_2.feeling: Engaged, affectionate portrait that sketches a restless, searching life without hagiography

path_2.title: The Shape of Water (2017)
path_2.feeling: A lush fairy‑tale romance whose empathy charmed me more than its pulp thrills

path_2.title: Trouble with Harry, The (1955)
path_2.feeling: A droll, gently morbid romp—pleasantly wry rather than piercing

path_2.title: Wedding Singer, The (1998)
path_2.feeling: Sweet, scruffy comfort food with a winning sincerity, if little aftertaste

path_2.title: One Day in September (1999)
path_2.feeling: Clear, sobering reportage that grips without sensationalizing

path_2.title: Roger & Me (1989)
path_2.feeling: Pointed and personable, though its blunt tactics sometimes undercut the sadness

path_2.title: Kid, The (1921)
path_2.feeling: Open‑hearted slapstick folded into genuine ache—simple, warm, and enduring

path_2.title: Vivre sa vie: Film en douze tableaux (My Life to Live) (1962)
path_2.feeling: Coolly composed yet piercingly humane

path_2.title: Crimes and Misdemeanors (1989)
path_2.feeling: Wry moral calculus that intrigues intellectually more than it moves me

path_2.title: Election (1999)
path_2.feeling: A razor‑sharp, compassionately cruel satire that sees everyone’s flaws clearly

path_2.title: Men in Black (a.k.a. MIB) (1997)
path_2.feeling: A breezy, clever romp, but the quippy spectacle rarely stirred me.

path_2.title: Herbie Goes Bananas (1980)
path_2.feeling: Featherweight hijinks that skim by without much charm for me.

path_2.title: Waking Life (2001)
path_2.feeling: Brainy, drifting conversations I often savored, even when the noodling got precious.

path_2.title: Addams Family Values (1993)
path_2.feeling: Delightfully macabre and campy, with a sly warmth under the black eyeliner.

path_2.title: Office Space (1999)
path_2.feeling: Slackers’ revolt with a deadpan pulse

path_2.title: Match Point (2005)
path_2.feeling: Sleek and watchable, but its moral chill left me more impressed than moved.

path_2.title: Shoah (1985)
path_2.feeling: Monumental, patient testimony that overwhelmed me with its humane rigor.

path_2.title: Greed (1924)
path_2.feeling: A stark, pitiless fable whose human details still bite.

path_2.title: Brazil (1985)
path_2.feeling: Dazzling, dense satire—invigorating, if occasionally suffocating.

path_2.title: Fly, The (1958)
path_2.feeling: Poised and melancholy pulp that intrigues more than it unnerves.

path_2.title: Sound of Music, The (1965)
path_2.feeling: Polished and buoyant, yet its sugar rush kept me at arm’s length.

path_2.title: District 9 (2009)
path_2.feeling: A noisy allegory whose grim spectacle alienated me.

path_2.title: Happy Accidents (2000)
path_2.feeling: Sweetly odd and sincere, its time-travel whimsy mostly worked on me.

path_2.title: Limitless (2011)
path_2.feeling: A slick, propulsive what-if that entertains even as it skims the surface.

path_2.feeling: A hushed, unsettling portrait of alienation that lingered like vapor.

path_2.title: Cross of Iron (1977)
path_2.feeling: Gritty and muscular, but emotionally kept me at medium distance.

path_2.feeling: Plainspoken, tender western melodrama that moved me in modest waves.

path_2.feeling: Engaging, affectionate chronicle that sketches the man more than it penetrates him.

path_2.feeling: Lush and earnest, a romantic fable that charmed if not deeply shook me.

path_2.title: Trouble with Harry, The (1955)
path_2.feeling: Wry and gently morbid, a pleasant curio with a light touch.

path_2.feeling: Sweet enough, though the broad schmaltz dulled the spark.

path_2.feeling: Clear, sobering reportage that gripped and chilled me.

path_2.feeling: Ragged but pointed, its scrappy compassion lands.

path_2.feeling: Tender, funny, and humane—the ache sneaks up on you.

path_3.title: Men in Black (a.k.a. MIB) (1997)
path_3.feeling: Lightly amused by its breezy silliness, then left a bit detached by the bombast.

path_3.title: Herbie Goes Bananas (1980)
path_3.feeling: A few cute beats, but I drifted through its thin, sugary antics.

path_3.title: Waking Life (2001)
path_3.feeling: Stimulated and drowsy in turns, I drifted with its talky dream.

path_3.title: Addams Family Values (1993)
path_3.feeling: Delighted by its arch mischief, even if it’s candy.

path_3.title: Office Space (1999)
path_3.feeling: I smirked often and winced at the cubicle truths.

path_3.title: Match Point (2005)
path_3.feeling: I admired the chilly craft but felt little beyond its cynicism.

path_3.title: Shoah (1985)
path_3.feeling: Drained, humbled, and quietly shaken by its grave testimony.

path_3.title: Greed (1924)
path_3.feeling: Impressed by its stark fatalism, I left somber rather than swept away.

path_3.title: Brazil (1985)
path_3.feeling: Dazzled and weary in equal measure, more spectacle than feeling for me.

path_3.title: Fly, The (1958)
path_3.feeling: Curious and a little chilled by its tragic premise, if dated.

path_3.title: Sound of Music, The (1965)
path_3.feeling: Swept along by its earnest warmth despite my limited sugar tolerance.

path_3.title: District 9 (2009)
path_3.feeling: Bludgeoned by its aggression, the allegory left me cold.

path_3.title: Happy Accidents (2000)
path_3.feeling: Charmed by its odd sincerity, even as the conceit wobbled.

path_3.title: Limitless (2011)
path_3.feeling: A glossy thought experiment that entertained me more than it moved me.

path_3.title: Safe (1995)
path_3.feeling: I left unsettled and pensive, gripped by its queasy, empathic hush.

path_3.title: Cross of Iron (1977)
path_3.feeling: Grimy and tense, something I respected more than I felt.

path_3.title: The Proud Rebel (1958)
path_3.feeling: Touched by its gentleness but not deeply stirred.

path_3.title: Squid and the Whale, The (2005)
path_3.feeling: Engaged and a little bruised by its tart honesty.

path_3.title: Life and Times of Allen Ginsberg, The (1994)
path_3.feeling: Interested and moved in parts, more a portrait of aura than access.

path_3.title: The Shape of Water (2017)
path_3.feeling: I enjoyed its tender oddity, though the fairy-tale gloss kept me at arm’s length.

path_3.title: Trouble with Harry, The (1955)
path_3.feeling: Amused by its morbid lightness more than invested.

path_3.title: Wedding Singer, The (1998)
path_3.feeling: Pleasantly buoyed by its goofy heart, then gone from my mind.

path_3.title: One Day in September (1999)
path_3.feeling: I left tense and sober, absorbing its clear-eyed accounting.

path_3.title: Roger & Me (1989)
path_3.feeling: Provoked and saddened, even as the shtick wore thin.

path_3.title: Kid, The (1921)
path_3.feeling: Warmed and a little teary at its simple, humane grace.

path_3.title: Vivre sa vie: Film en douze tableaux (My Life to Live) (1962)
path_3.feeling: Contemplative and piercing, I felt quietly undone by its gaze.

path_3.title: Crimes and Misdemeanors (1989)
path_3.feeling: Engaged by its moral murk, though the prevailing cynicism left a chill.

path_3.title: Election (1999)
path_3.feeling: Amused yet put off by its acid bite.

path_3.title: Men in Black (a.k.a. MIB) (1997)
path_3.feeling: Amused by the breezy wit but rarely moved.

path_3.title: Herbie Goes Bananas (1980)
path_3.feeling: Light and disposable

path_3.title: Waking Life (2001)
path_3.feeling: Drifty, talky dreams left me stimulated more than stirred.

path_3.title: Addams Family Values (1993)
path_3.feeling: Delightfully barbed and camp, it charmed without cutting deep.

path_3.title: Office Space (1999)
path_3.feeling: I chuckled and winced, seeing the deadpan despair of routine.

path_3.title: Match Point (2005)
path_3.feeling: I admired the craft but felt chilled by its slick cynicism.

path_3.title: Shoah (1985)
path_3.feeling: I left hushed and shaken by its rigorous, witness-driven moral weight.

path_3.title: Greed (1924)
path_3.feeling: Bleak and absorbing, it left a lingering ache over human grasping.

path_3.title: Brazil (1985)
path_3.feeling: Dazzled and distanced, I admired the nightmare scaffolding more than I felt it.

path_3.title: Fly, The (1958)
path_3.feeling: A tidy cautionary fable that intrigued more than it haunted.

path_3.title: Sound of Music, The (1965)
path_3.feeling: Warm and well-made, it left me lightly humming, a touch wistful.

path_3.title: District 9 (2009)
path_3.feeling: Its bombast and bleakness kept me at arm’s length.

path_3.title: Happy Accidents (2000)

path_3.title: Limitless (2011)
path_3.feeling: A sleek idea that entertained me more than it moved me.

path_3.title: Safe (1995)
path_3.feeling: Quiet dread seeped in until I was unnervingly hollowed out.

path_3.title: Cross of Iron (1977)
path_3.feeling: Gritty and competently mounted, yet the war roar muted my empathy.

path_3.title: The Proud Rebel (1958)
path_3.feeling: Gentle and earnest, it touched me lightly without lasting.

path_3.title: Life and Times of Allen Ginsberg, The (1994)
path_3.feeling: Engaging portrait that stirred more curiosity than revelation.

path_3.title: The Shape of Water (2017)
path_3.feeling: A tender fairy tale that warmed me more than it overwhelmed me.

path_3.title: Trouble with Harry, The (1955)
path_3.feeling: Droll and airy, a pleasant diversion that drifted away.

path_3.title: Wedding Singer, The (1998)
path_3.feeling: Cute and cozy, I smiled but felt little beyond the nostalgia.

path_3.title: One Day in September (1999)
path_3.feeling: Tense and sobering, I left alert to the failures and costs.

path_3.title: Roger & Me (1989)

path_3.title: Kid, The (1921)
path_3.feeling: I left misty-eyed, held by its tender, humane glow.

path_3.title: Vivre sa vie: Film en douze tableaux (My Life to Live) (1962)
path_3.feeling: Coolly precise yet aching, it left me quietly pensive.

path_3.title: Crimes and Misdemeanors (1989)
path_3.feeling: Moral unease lingered, sharpened by dry wit and regret.

path_3.title: Election (1999)
path_3.feeling: Acerbic and clear-eyed, it left me amused and a little stung.

path_3.title: Men in Black (a.k.a. MIB) (1997)
path_3.feeling: Amused by its slick bounce but kept at arm's length by the quippy bombast.

path_3.title: Herbie Goes Bananas (1980)
path_3.feeling: Too sugary and flimsy for me, I drifted out unengaged.

path_3.title: Waking Life (2001)
path_3.feeling: I left gently buzzing, more stirred by its drifting ideas than its form.

path_3.title: Addams Family Values (1993)
path_3.feeling: Dryly delighted by its macabre wit, more charmed than moved.

path_3.title: Office Space (1999)
path_3.feeling: I felt wryly seen by its cubicle malaise, even as the caper felt slight.

path_3.title: Match Point (2005)
path_3.feeling: Impressed by the icy control but chilled by its moral emptiness.

path_3.title: Shoah (1985)
path_3.feeling: I left hushed and shaken by its unblinking testimonies.

path_3.title: Greed (1924)
path_3.feeling: I felt absorbed by its stark fatalism and human pettiness.

path_3.title: Brazil (1985)
path_3.feeling: I admired its fevered imagination, more dazzled by the world than invested in the plot.

path_3.title: Fly, The (1958)
path_3.feeling: Quietly unsettled, I was moved more by its tragedy than its thrills.

path_3.title: Sound of Music, The (1965)
path_3.feeling: Wistful and warm, though its sweetness sometimes kept me at a distance.

path_3.title: District 9 (2009)
path_3.feeling: I left numb from its bludgeoning allegory despite flashes of empathy.

path_3.title: Happy Accidents (2000)
path_3.feeling: Gently charmed by its oddball tenderness, I forgave the wobbly conceit.

path_3.title: Limitless (2011)
path_3.feeling: Sleekly entertaining, I admired the premise more than its swagger.

path_3.title: Safe (1995)
path_3.feeling: I walked away quietly rattled and enthralled by its suffocating, ambiguous dread.

path_3.title: Cross of Iron (1977)
path_3.feeling: Grimly compelling craft, but the macho churn kept me cool.

path_3.title: The Proud Rebel (1958)
path_3.feeling: I felt softly stirred by its spare decency and father-son ache.

path_3.title: Squid and the Whale, The (2005)
path_3.feeling: I left wincing and tender, impressed by its prickly honesty.

path_3.title: Life and Times of Allen Ginsberg, The (1994)
path_3.feeling: I felt curious and warmed by his restless, unruly spirit more than the form.

path_3.title: The Shape of Water (2017)
path_3.feeling: I was gently moved by its fairytale compassion, if wary of its gloss.

path_3.title: Trouble with Harry, The (1955)
path_3.feeling: Amused by its dry morbidity, pleasantly slight.

path_3.title: Wedding Singer, The (1998)
path_3.feeling: Lightly sweet and harmless, but it barely grazed me.

path_3.title: One Day in September (1999)
path_3.feeling: I left tense and sorrowful, sobered by its clear, unsparing account.

path_3.title: Roger & Me (1989)
path_3.feeling: I admired the outrage and humor, even as the tactics felt blunt.

path_3.title: Kid, The (1921)
path_3.feeling: I felt tender and heartsore at its simple, generous humanity.

path_3.title: Vivre sa vie: Film en douze tableaux (My Life to Live) (1962)
path_3.feeling: I drifted out hushed, moved by its cool gaze and fragile defiance.

path_3.title: Crimes and Misdemeanors (1989)
path_3.feeling: I left uneasy, admiring its moral weight more than its chill.

path_3.title: Election (1999)
path_3.feeling: Sharply funny and acidic, I enjoyed the sting more than the sneer.

path_3.title: Men in Black (a.k.a. MIB) (1997)
path_3.feeling: Lightly amused by its sleek deadpan charm, I still felt kept at a cool distance.

path_3.title: Herbie Goes Bananas (1980)
path_3.feeling: Lightly amused but rarely moved, its sugary antics slid right off me.

path_3.title: Waking Life (2001)
path_3.feeling: Stimulated and a bit adrift, I left thoughtful more than moved.

path_3.title: Addams Family Values (1993)
path_3.feeling: Delighted by its mordant wit and oddball familial warmth.

path_3.title: Office Space (1999)
path_3.feeling: Wryly seen by its cubicle malaise, I chuckled and winced in equal measure.

path_3.title: Match Point (2005)
path_3.feeling: Absorbed by its moral rot yet cooled by the slick cynicism.

path_3.title: Shoah (1985)
path_3.feeling: I left shaken and hushed, humbled by its relentless, humane testimony.

path_3.title: Greed (1924)
path_3.feeling: I felt gripped by its stark, unforgiving anatomy of desire.

path_3.title: Brazil (1985)
path_3.feeling: Enchanted by its melancholy absurdity more than its frantic sprawl.

path_3.title: Fly, The (1958)
path_3.feeling: Intrigued by its tragic conceit but only lightly chilled by the telling.

path_3.title: Sound of Music, The (1965)
path_3.feeling: Warmed by its generous heart and song, even as the sugar sometimes numbed me.

path_3.title: District 9 (2009)
path_3.feeling: Put off by its blunt allegory and jittery cruelty, I stayed distant.

path_3.title: Happy Accidents (2000)
path_3.feeling: Charmed by its earnest oddball tenderness more than its sci-fi contrivance.

path_3.title: Limitless (2011)
path_3.feeling: Entertained by its slick momentum, admiring the idea more than the swagger.

path_3.title: Safe (1995)
path_3.feeling: I left hushed and uneasy, drawn into its suffocating, ambiguous illness and suburban dread.

path_3.title: Cross of Iron (1977)
path_3.feeling: Impressed by the muddy ferocity, held at arm’s length by the macho grind.

path_3.title: The Proud Rebel (1958)
path_3.feeling: Softened by its gentle core, if not fully swept up by the frontier melodrama.

path_3.title: Squid and the Whale, The (2005)
path_3.feeling: Pained and engaged by its prickly honesty about a family in free fall.

path_3.title: Life and Times of Allen Ginsberg, The (1994)
path_3.feeling: Interested and moved in parts, it felt more sketchbook than revelation.

path_3.title: The Shape of Water (2017)
path_3.feeling: Touched by its tender odd romance, less by its broad fairy-tale strokes.

path_3.title: Trouble with Harry, The (1955)
path_3.feeling: Pleasantly droll, more a fond smile than a stir.

path_3.title: Wedding Singer, The (1998)
path_3.feeling: Sweet enough, but the broad goofiness kept me at a distance.

path_3.title: One Day in September (1999)
path_3.feeling: Galvanized and heartsore by its clear, chilling account.

path_3.title: Roger & Me (1989)
path_3.feeling: Engaged by its scrappy outrage, even as the tactics felt blunt.

path_3.title: Kid, The (1921)
path_3.feeling: I felt cradled by its openhearted pathos and playful grace.

path_3.title: Vivre sa vie: Film en douze tableaux (My Life to Live) (1962)
path_3.feeling: Hushed and compelled by its lucid gaze and fatal drift.

path_3.title: Crimes and Misdemeanors (1989)
path_3.feeling: Absorbed and unsettled by its cool tangle of guilt, faith, and compromise.

path_3.title: Election (1999)
path_3.feeling: Wickedly amused and a little heartsore at its ruthless smallness.

path_5.feeling: Acerbic divorce memoir with prickly honesty that I appreciate even when it needles.

path_5.title: Life and Times of Allen Ginsberg, The (1994)
path_5.feeling: Expansive, humane portrait of a restless artist-activist that aligns with my interests.

path_5.title: The Shape of Water (2017)
path_5.feeling: Tender, oddball fairy tale whose romance and empathy win out over the thriller trappings.

path_5.title: Trouble with Harry, The (1955)
path_5.feeling: Wry, quaint corpse caper that charms lightly without fully sweeping me up.

path_5.title: Wedding Singer, The (1998)
path_5.feeling: Sweet, retro romcom comfort that goes down easy if predictably.

path_5.title: One Day in September (1999)
path_5.feeling: Clear‑eyed, sobering account whose tension and moral complexity keep me rapt.

path_5.title: Roger & Me (1989)
path_5.feeling: Punchy, populist doc that engages me even as the stunts feel a bit broad.

path_5.title: Kid, The (1921)
path_5.feeling: Warm, humane Chaplin blend of slapstick and ache that still moves me.

path_5.title: Vivre sa vie: Film en douze tableaux (My Life to Live) (1962)
path_5.feeling: Cool, searching portrait of a young woman that fits my contemplative, feminist-leaning tastes.

path_5.title: Crimes and Misdemeanors (1989)
path_5.feeling: Wry moral tangle I respect intellectually more than I feel emotionally.

path_5.title: Election (1999)
path_5.feeling: Sharply barbed civics satire whose wit and bite suit me fine.

path_5.title: Men in Black (a.k.a. MIB) (1997)
path_5.feeling: Slick, quippy alien-cop lark that amuses me more than it moves me.

path_5.title: Herbie Goes Bananas (1980)
path_5.feeling: Featherweight, corny caper whose mild charms fade quickly for me.

path_5.title: Waking Life (2001)
path_5.feeling: A talky, lucid-dream drift that scratches my contemplative itch even when some riffs sprawl.

path_5.title: Addams Family Values (1993)
path_5.feeling: Macabre, witty sequel whose deadpan bite and oddball heart keep me smiling.

path_5.title: Office Space (1999)
path_5.feeling: Cubicle-malaise satire that hits enough nerves to amuse me, even as the hijinks get broad.

path_5.title: Match Point (2005)
path_5.feeling: A sleek, chilly social-climb noir I respect more than I enjoy.

path_5.title: Shoah (1985)
path_5.feeling: Monumental, unflinching testimony that commands deep respect and quiet attention.

path_5.title: Greed (1924)
path_5.feeling: A bleak, human-frailty epic whose stark power outweighs its longueurs.

path_5.title: Brazil (1985)
path_5.feeling: A baroque dystopian nightmare whose satire and imagination light me up even as the chaos wears me down.

path_5.title: Fly, The (1958)
path_5.feeling: A tragic sci-fi morality tale that engages me more for mood than for shocks.

path_5.title: Sound of Music, The (1965)
path_5.feeling: Sweeping, wholesome musical whose craft and heart win me over despite the syrup.

path_5.title: District 9 (2009)
path_5.feeling: Grimy, aggressive allegory whose relentless violence and macho energy wear me out.

path_5.title: Happy Accidents (2000)
path_5.feeling: An offbeat, tender time-twist romance that hits my sweet spot for humane, low-key sci-fi.

path_5.title: Limitless (2011)
path_5.feeling: Slick pop-sci thriller whose ideas and momentum work for me despite the gloss.

path_5.title: Safe (1995)
path_5.feeling: A chilling, quietly humane portrait of malaise that fits my contemplative appetite.

path_5.title: Cross of Iron (1977)
path_5.feeling: Gritty war clash I respect more than I love.

path_5.title: The Proud Rebel (1958)
path_5.feeling: A gentle, humane frontier drama that plays to my soft spot for resilience.

path_5.title: Squid and the Whale, The (2005)
path_5.feeling: Acerbic, intimate divorce fallout that resonates despite the prickly characters.

path_5.title: Life and Times of Allen Ginsberg, The (1994)
path_5.feeling: An engaging, humane portrait whose cultural currents speak to me more than the hagiography.

path_5.title: The Shape of Water (2017)
path_5.feeling: A lush, compassionate fairy tale I like, even as the thriller gears feel a bit loud.

path_5.title: Trouble with Harry, The (1955)
path_5.feeling: Dry, droll small-town morbid farce that keeps me pleasantly amused.

path_5.title: Wedding Singer, The (1998)
path_5.feeling: Sweet, goofy rom-com comfort that goes down easy if a bit syrupy.

path_5.title: One Day in September (1999)
path_5.feeling: A clear, sobering account that engages my concern more than my awe.

path_5.title: Roger & Me (1989)
path_5.feeling: Acerbic, accessible corporate critique that scratches my civic itch despite some showboating.

path_5.title: Kid, The (1921)
path_5.feeling: Tender, funny heart-tug that lands squarely for me.

path_5.title: Vivre sa vie: Film en douze tableaux (My Life to Live) (1962)
path_5.feeling: Formally sharp, compassionate portrait I admire, even if its detachment cools me a bit.

path_5.title: Crimes and Misdemeanors (1989)
path_5.feeling: A nimble moral tangle I appreciate intellectually more than I love.

path_5.title: Election (1999)
path_5.feeling: Acid, funny civics-in-miniature that hits my satire sweet spot.
